STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 14, 2019
Shaun Culp
Calhoun County DHHS
PO Box 490
Battle Creek, MI 49017
RE: License #: CP130201006
Calhoun County DHHS
190 E. Michigan Avenue
Battle Creek, MI 49016-0490
Dear Mr. Culp:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 9/23/19.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and ISEP
requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that violations
of any licensing rules are also violations of the ISEP and your contract. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For any repeat
violations, please identify from the previous CAP what areas worked, and
what changes will be made to address the repeat violation.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (269) 337-5289.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP130201006
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Shaun Culp, Administrator
Name of Facility: Calhoun County DHHS
Facility Address: 190 E. Michigan Avenue
Battle Creek, MI 49016-0490
Facility Telephone #: (269) 966-1414
Original Issuance Date: 02/01/1992
Service Types:
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 09/9/2019 - 09/23/2019

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have training in
and maintain a current certification in first aid from the American
Heart Association or the American Red Cross or other institution
approved by the department.
Four of six foster home files reviewed did not have documentation that an adult
household member had current training in CPR.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(2) The annual reevaluation shall include a determination and
assessment of all of the following:
(d) Compliance with the licensing rules for foster homes.
Four of four foster home evaluations reviewed did not contain all the required information
to establish compliance with each rule. Specifically, one report did not include adequate
information regarding compliance with foster home rule 400.9305(2) as the report does
not answer the question “what is the water temperature” posed within the report
template. Additionally, four reports did not include adequate information regarding foster
home rule 400.9411(4) as none of the reports include dates the emergency procedures
were practiced as required within the report template. Two of the four reports did not
mention that any practices were completed by the family and two indicated how often
they were completed, but did not provide the specific dates. Additionally, no record of the
emergency evacuation dates of practice were located within any of the files.
R 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15 calendar
days before the expiration date of the foster home license.
One of three renewal reports reviewed was not completed within the required timeframe.
This report was completed on 1/3/19, despite the license expiring on 1/8/29.
This is a repeat violation:
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
4

R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an agency
shall complete a written report that includes all of the following
information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One of two special evaluation reports reviewed indicated that the family was not in
compliance with all licensing rules, yet the family was found to be in compliance.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs…
Two of eight foster care case files did not have the proper documentation (DHHS 69) to
document a change of placement.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a minimum,
include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older, including
both of the following:
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every 18
months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight foster care files had a missed dental exam.
This is a repeat violation:
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the following
information before the placement or replacement of a child: (j)
Authorization to provide routine and emergency medical care.
5

Two of eight foster care files did not have documentation that a medical card (DHHS-
3762) was provided to the caregiver at the time of replacement.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child and
parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at least
once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of eight foster care files had late USPs.
FC1: 10/16/18 USP was completed eight days late.
FC 2: 2/12/19 USP was completed twenty days late.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16
10/27/17 interim evaluation; CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
R 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a youth
before placement in independent living.
One of three IL case files did not have verification that a program statement was
provided to the youth prior to placement.
This is a repeat violation:
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
R 400.12507 Medical/dental and mental health care
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living
receives any needed medical, dental, and mental health care as
required in R400.12413. Medical, dental, and mental health care
provided shall be documented in the youth’s record.
6

One of three IL files had a late medical. The medical was due by 6/18/19, but was not
completed until 6/25/19.
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
(1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
independent living as the most appropriate placement for the youth.
Two of three IL case files did not document this requirement. In both cases, the youth
returned from AWOL and were placed in IL. There was no documented rational for
determining the appropriateness of this placement.
This is a repeat violation from the 9/14/18 renewal evaluation CAP approved
10/3/18.
R 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision: (a)
Face to face contact between the social service worker and the youth
in independent living at least once each month at a youth’s place of
residence.
One of three IL case files was missing face to face contact for December 2018 and July
2019. It was noted several attempts were made. However, the youth did not comply with
visitation requirements.
R 400.12505 Supervision
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is complying with the
terms of the contract required by R400.12510 continues to reside in a
safe and acceptable environment, and is managing expenditures.
One of three IL files did not have any monthly budgets on file from November 2018 to
April 2019.
R 400.12510 Independent Living contract
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth and the
social service worker. The contract shall be reviewed and updated at
least once every 90 calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
7

One of three IL case files did not have a contract signed by the youth every 90 days.
Contracts were on file for 10/1/18, 1/4/19, 4/19/19 and 5/29/19. However, none of them
were signed by the youth.
This is a repeat violation:
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
R 400.12509 Independent Living record
(3) The case record shall contain all of the following information and
documentation, which shall be recorded within 30 calendar days after
placement in independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R 400.12420.
One of three IL case files did not have a service plan completed within 30 days of the
youth entering IL (7/17/19).
R 400.12504 Eligibility requirements
(2) All of the following shall be in the case record before a youth is
placed in independent living: (a) How the youth meets the eligibility
requirements for the specific program the youth is being placed into.
Two of three IL files did not meet this requirement.
IL 1: No IL eligibility verification on file. YAVFC eligibility did not have any
documentation. Case file does not identify any current employment or education to
maintain eligibility, as required by the agency’s policy FOM 722-16 (Page 2).
IL 2: No IL eligibility verification on file. The case file documents that the youth is not
employed or attending school, as required by the agency’s policy FOM 722-16 (Page 2).
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures
(1)An agency shall have and follow written policies and procedures
for the foster care services provided. (2) The policies and procedure
shall cover at least all of the following areas: (j) Visitation.
8

Six of eight foster care cases did not meet the agency’s policy requirements for visitation
with youth, siblings, or parents.
FC 1: No parenting time documented since 7/17/19 and no exception on file.
FC 2: No parenting time documented for November 2018 and January 2019, and no
exception on file.
FC 3:No parenting time from 12/12/18 to 3/27/19, and no exception on file. Only one
parental home visit during this review period. Only one sibling visit during this review
period.
FC 4: No worker contact at parental home since May 2019.
FC 5: No worker contact in placement for December 2018.
FC 6: No parenting time documented for March 2019.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance with all additional ISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS Contract violation. Please note that
there are additional DHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Contract/Policy
requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-03 Placement Exception Request
Page 14-16
Caseworkers must complete a placement exception request (PER)
when there is a need to waive placement standards to maintain
sibling and caregiver bonds or to meet the medical, emotional, and
psychological needs of children in care. PERs must be completed,
reviewed, and approved in MiSACWIS.
One of eight foster care case files did not have an approved PER in place for a sibling
split.
Two of two foster home files that were required to have PERs to address the number of
approved children in the home, did not have approved PERs on file.
FOM 801 Medical Passport
Page 11-13
All medical information within the medical passport must be current
and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current and
complete health information.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Legal parents, if the child is a temporary court ward. Quarterly. At
reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider: At or prior to each placement.
Quarterly.
9

• All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child is
newly referred to and accepted for treatment and/or services prior to
or at the first scheduled appointment.
• Older youth
Three of eight foster care case files were missing updated medical passports.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16
10/27/17 interim evaluation; CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
Page 1-7
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined.
Five of eleven foster care and independent living cases did not hold FTMs as required.
FC 1: 10/16/18 USP did not have an FTM prior to report approval
FC 2: 11/14/18 and 2/12/19 USPs did not have an FTM prior to report approval
FC 3: An FTM was not completed for the 5/1/19 replacement
IL 1: No Semi-Annual Transition plan FTM. No return from AWOL, or entrance into
YAVFC FTM.
IL 2: No Semi-Annual Transition plan FTM. No FTM for return from AWOL or 11/26/18
USP.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16
10/27/17 interim evaluation; CAP approved 11/28/17
9/14/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/18
FOM 722-08C Parent Agency Treatment Plan- required participation in
Page 2 development
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor, foster
parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the case of
placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
10

Four of eight foster care cases did not have required PATP signatures.
FC 1: 12/20/18 PATP missing youth signature.
FC 2: All 4 PATPs reviewed were missing caregiver signature.
FC 3: December 2018, February, May 2019 PATP missing parent signature.
FC 4: One PATP missing youth signature, two PATPs signed by youth but outside of 30
day timeframe required.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16.
10/27/17 interim evaluation, CAP approved 11/28/17
9/11/19 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/3/19
FOM 722-06H Timely Entry of Caseworker Contacts
All caseworker contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS; this includes
attempted contacts and missed appointments, and all pertinent
information obtained must be summarized and included in the
appropriate section of the case service plan.
All face-to-face contacts must be entered in MiSACWIS, within five
business days of the contact.
Two of eight case files held face to face contacts that were not entered within the
required five business day timeframe.
This is a repeat violation:
9/7/16 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 9/14/16
10/27/17 interim evaluation; CAP approved 11/28/17
9/11/18 renewal evaluation, CAP approved 10/2/18
ANALYST INFORMATION
No safety concerns were reported to the DCWL Analyst.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Case contacts- During the review it was noted that some parenting time and home
visit contacts were sparse, with little detail. The agency was advised that contacts,
such as parenting time, need to thoroughly document interactions, as these contacts
have great bearing in service plans and court reports.
Youth Photos- One youth photo was observed to be very dark and grainy, making it
almost impossible to see the youth. The agency was reminded that photos must be
clear.
11

Service Plans- Several USPs were not generated and saved in MiSACWIS.
Therefore, they could not be accessed as a .pdf document for review. The agency
was reminded that that the reports must be generated and saved.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not requested during this review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP was approved on 10/3/18, after
the 9/14/18 renewal evaluation. The evaluation had a significant number of
violations, which has decreased substantially during this review period: 28 violations
in 2018 compared to 22 violations in 2019. The agency’s thorough CAP and ongoing
efforts over the past year have provided staff with additional training and more
streamlined processes. In addition, the agency was able to hire additional staff,
which has aided in compliance. These efforts have decreased the number of
violations, as well as decreased the occurrence of each violation. Overall, the
agency has shown significant improvement and continues to follow and adjust their
CAP as needed.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules, ISEP requirements, and contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 9, 2019
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
12

October 14, 2019
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
13
